questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents with symptoms of fever, chills, malaise, and joint discomfort in his hands and knees. He looks unwell, his temperature is 39.4°C, blood pressure 116/70 mm Hg, pulse 110/min, head and neck is normal, and his jugular venous pressure (JVP) has a prominent c-v wave. There is also a 3/6 pansystolic murmur heard at the right sternal border that increases with respiration. His lungs are clear, abdomen is soft, and hand joints are normal. He has multiple puncture sites on his forearms from injection drug use. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Staphylococcus aureus. This patient presents with symptoms suggestive of infective endocarditis (IE), including fever, chills, malaise, and a pansystolic murmur. His history of injection drug use (IDU) and the clinical finding of a prominent c-v wave in the jugular venous pressure, indicative of tricuspid valve involvement, strongly point toward Staphylococcus aureus as the causative organism. Staphylococcus aureus is the most common pathogen associated with IE in injection drug users, as it can directly invade normal heart valves, particularly the tricuspid valve. This organism is highly virulent, often causing acute presentations with systemic toxicity and rapid valve destruction. Incorrect Options: B. Staphylococcus epidermidis: While this organism is a common cause of IE, it is primarily associated with prosthetic valve infections and infections in patients with indwelling catheters or implanted devices. This patient's lack of prosthetic material or such devices makes Staphylococcus epidermidis an unlikely cause in this scenario. C. Streptococcus viridans: Streptococcus viridans is a common cause of subacute infective endocarditis, typically affecting patients with pre-existing valvular abnormalities, such as rheumatic heart disease or mitral valve prolapse. It is less likely in injection drug users and is associated with dental procedures or poor dental hygiene. The acute presentation in this patient and the lack of predisposing valvular disease make Streptococcus viridans an improbable cause. D. Enterococci: Enterococci, particularly Enterococcus faecalis, are a cause of IE in older adults and those with genitourinary or gastrointestinal procedures. They are less commonly associated with IDU. The lack of history suggestive of such procedures and the acute presentation make Enterococci an unlikely causative agent.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presented in gynecology OPD with complaints of ulcerative lesions on her vulvar area. These lesions are recurrent. She also has fever, malaise and anorexia. Recently she has noticed dysuria. On examination temperature is 99 F, local examination revealed vesicular lesions on an erythematous base on her vulvar area. She has tender lymphadenopathy in inguinal area. Lab tests including CBC and plasma glucose are normal. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Herpes simplex virus type 2 (HSV-2). This patient's clinical presentation, including recurrent ulcerative lesions on the vulvar area, vesicular lesions on an erythematous base, fever, malaise, anorexia, and tender inguinal lymphadenopathy, is highly characteristic of genital herpes caused by HSV-2. Genital herpes often begins with systemic symptoms like fever and malaise, followed by painful vesicles that evolve into ulcers. The recurrent nature of the lesions further supports HSV-2 as the most likely causative organism since this virus remains latent in the sacral ganglia and can reactivate periodically. Dysuria is another common symptom in genital herpes, often due to vulvar irritation. Incorrect Options: A. Cytomegalovirus (CMV): While CMV can cause genital ulceration, it is a rare cause and typically occurs in immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV/AIDS or organ transplants. This patient does not have any known immunosuppressive condition, making CMV an unlikely cause. B. Gonococcus: Neisseria gonorrhoeae (gonococcus) causes gonorrhea, which typically presents with cervicitis, urethritis, or pelvic inflammatory disease. It does not usually cause vesicular or ulcerative lesions. While dysuria is common in gonorrhea, the absence of purulent discharge and the presence of vesicular lesions strongly argue against gonococcus as the cause. D. Treponema pallidum: Treponema pallidum causes syphilis, which can present with genital ulcers. However, the ulcers of primary syphilis (chancres) are typically painless, firm, and not associated with vesicles. This patient's painful vesicular lesions and systemic symptoms are inconsistent with the presentation of syphilis, making it an unlikely cause.

questions.text: A 17-year-old man presents with new symptoms of fatigue, malaise, fever, and a sore throat. He has no significant past medical history and is not on any medications. Physical examination is entirely normal except for enlarged, palpable cervical, lymph nodes. He reports no weight loss or night sweats. Laboratory investigations include a normal chest x-ray, negative throat swab, but abnormal blood film with atypical lymphocytes. The hemoglobin is 15.5 g/dL; hematocrit 42%; platelets 290,000/mL; WBC 10500/mL, with 45% segmented neutrophils, 1% eosinophils, and 54% lymphocytes, of which 36% were atypical. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial diagnostic test?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Heterophil antibody (sheep cell agglutination) test. This patient's symptoms of fatigue, malaise, fever, sore throat, and cervical lymphadenopathy, combined with the presence of atypical lymphocytes on the blood film, are highly suggestive of infectious mononucleosis (IM). The heterophil antibody test (also known as the Monospot test) is a rapid and specific diagnostic test for Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), the most common cause of IM. The test detects heterophil antibodies produced in response to EBV infection, which are present in the majority of cases of IM. Given the classic presentation and laboratory findings, this test is the most appropriate initial diagnostic step. Incorrect Options: A. Lymph node biopsy: A lymph node biopsy is typically reserved for evaluating lymphadenopathy suspicious for malignancies like lymphoma. This patient has no "red flag" features such as weight loss, night sweats, or generalized lymphadenopathy to suggest lymphoma. Additionally, the presence of atypical lymphocytes and systemic symptoms makes a viral infection (like IM) much more likely. B. Bone marrow: A bone marrow biopsy is performed to evaluate hematological malignancies or unexplained cytopenias. This patient's complete blood count is normal except for the presence of atypical lymphocytes, which are characteristic of viral infections such as IM. Bone marrow examination is invasive and unnecessary in this scenario. C. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR): ESR is a nonspecific test that may be elevated in various conditions, including infections and inflammatory diseases. While it could be mildly elevated in IM, it does not provide a definitive diagnosis or additional information in this case. The heterophil antibody test is more specific and directly diagnostic.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man is traveling on business. He is staying in hotels and eating food in large restaurants. He has not eaten from street vendors. One week after arrival, he develops symptoms of anorexia, nausea, and abdominal cramps followed by the sudden onset of watery diarrhea. He has no fever or chills and there is no blood or pus in the stools. Which of the following is the most appropriate therapy for his condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Oral rehydration with loperamide. This patient’s presentation is consistent with traveler's diarrhea, characterized by anorexia, nausea, abdominal cramps, and watery diarrhea without fever or bloody stools. The most likely causative organisms are enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC) or other non-invasive pathogens. Oral rehydration is essential to prevent dehydration, and loperamide can be used to control symptoms of diarrhea, particularly in cases without fever or dysentery (blood or mucus in stools). This combination provides symptomatic relief while addressing the risk of dehydration, making it the most appropriate therapy in this case. Incorrect Options: A. Amoxicillin: Amoxicillin is not effective against the typical pathogens causing traveler’s diarrhea, such as ETEC. Furthermore, antibiotics are generally reserved for more severe cases involving high fever, bloody stools, or prolonged illness. The absence of these features in this patient makes amoxicillin inappropriate. C. Doxycycline: Doxycycline is an antibiotic that has been used prophylactically or therapeutically in certain infectious diarrheal illnesses, such as those caused by Vibrio cholerae. However, it is not the first-line treatment for uncomplicated traveler’s diarrhea. Its use is unnecessary here since the patient has mild symptoms without signs of systemic infection. D. Oral rehydration only: While oral rehydration is crucial to prevent dehydration, it does not address the patient’s symptoms of diarrhea and abdominal cramping. Adding loperamide provides symptomatic relief, which improves the patient’s comfort and allows for better functioning during travel. For mild, non-invasive diarrhea, combining oral rehydration with loperamide is superior to oral rehydration alone.

questions.text: An 18-year-old woman presents with headache, anorexia, chilly sensations, and discomfort on both sides of her jaw. She has also noticed discomfort in both lower abdominal quadrants. Physical examination reveals bilateral enlarged parotid glands that are doughy, elastic, and slightly tender; with a reddened orifice of Stensen’s duct. Her abdomen is soft with bilateral lower quadrant abdominal tenderness; a temperature of 38.5°C; and a pulse rate of 92/min. Laboratory data show hemoglobin 13 g/dL; hematocrit 40%; white blood cells (WBC) 9000/mL, with 35% segmented neutrophils, 7% monocytes, and 58% lymphocytes. Which of the following is the most likely cause for her abdominal pain and tenderness?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Oophoritis. This patient’s presentation is most consistent with mumps, a viral illness caused by the mumps virus. Her bilateral parotid gland enlargement, tenderness, fever, and elevated lymphocyte count support this diagnosis. In post-pubertal females, mumps can occasionally lead to oophoritis, an inflammation of the ovaries, which explains her bilateral lower abdominal tenderness. Oophoritis is a known complication of mumps in females, occurring in about 5% of post-pubertal cases. It typically presents with abdominal discomfort and tenderness in the lower quadrants, as observed in this patient. Incorrect Options: A. Mesenteric lymphadenitis: Mesenteric lymphadenitis, an inflammation of the lymph nodes in the abdomen, typically causes pain in the right lower quadrant and is often associated with conditions like viral infections or Yersinia enterocolitica infection. This patient’s bilateral lower quadrant tenderness and concurrent parotid gland enlargement make oophoritis due to mumps more likely than mesenteric lymphadenitis. C. Gonorrhea: Gonorrhea is a sexually transmitted infection that can cause pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), leading to lower abdominal pain. However, this patient’s presentation lacks key features of gonorrhea or PID, such as purulent vaginal discharge, dyspareunia, or cervical motion tenderness. Furthermore, the concurrent parotid gland swelling strongly points toward mumps as the underlying cause of her symptoms. D. Peritoneal metastases: Peritoneal metastases would typically occur in the context of advanced malignancy and present with symptoms such as ascites, weight loss, or systemic signs of cancer. This young patient has no history or clinical features suggestive of malignancy, making this diagnosis highly unlikely.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man, previously well, develops a fever and dry cough for last 2 week. On examination pulse is 110/min, BP-120/70 mmHg, his chest is clear and heart sounds are normal. A chest x-ray (CXR) reveals a diffuse interstitial infiltrate. Lab tests showed low Hb with increased reticulocyte count with positive coomb’s test. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Mycoplasma. This patient’s presentation, including a prolonged fever, dry cough, and chest X-ray showing diffuse interstitial infiltrates, is characteristic of atypical pneumonia caused by Mycoplasma pneumoniae. The additional findings of anemia with an increased reticulocyte count and a positive Coombs test indicate autoimmune hemolytic anemia, a known complication of Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection. Mycoplasma is a unique bacterial organism that lacks a cell wall, making it resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics, and it is a common cause of atypical pneumonia, especially in young adults. Incorrect Options: A. Bacterium: While Mycoplasma is technically a bacterium, this option likely refers to typical bacterial causes of pneumonia (e.g., Streptococcus pneumoniae or Haemophilus influenzae). These organisms cause lobar pneumonia with productive cough and localized findings on chest X-ray, which is inconsistent with this patient’s interstitial pattern and dry cough. Typical bacterial pneumonia also does not commonly cause autoimmune hemolytic anemia. C. Fungus: Fungal infections, such as histoplasmosis or coccidioidomycosis, can cause diffuse lung infiltrates, but they are typically associated with immunocompromised states or specific geographic exposures. This patient has no history or features suggestive of fungal infection, making this cause unlikely. D. Rickettsia: Rickettsial infections can cause systemic symptoms, fever, and interstitial infiltrates, but they are typically associated with a history of tick exposure and a rash. The absence of these features and the autoimmune hemolytic anemia make rickettsial infection less likely.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is admitted with fever and rust-colored sputum. He looks unwell, temperature 38.4°C, pulse 100/min, and blood pressure 115/80 mm Hg. On auscultation, there are bronchial breath sounds in the right axilla and inspiratory crackles. The CXR is shown in Figure.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Right middle lobe pneumonia. This patient presents with fever, rust-colored sputum, and findings of bronchial breath sounds and inspiratory crackles in the right axilla. These findings are classic for lobar pneumonia, specifically involving the right middle lobe. The rust-colored sputum is a hallmark of Streptococcus pneumoniae, the most common cause of community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). Bronchial breath sounds on auscultation indicate lung consolidation, and the clinical features, combined with imaging findings on the chest X-ray (CXR), typically show opacification localized to the affected lobe. Incorrect Options: B. Loculated pleural effusion: Loculated pleural effusion can present with fever and respiratory symptoms but usually shows a well-demarcated fluid collection on imaging, distinct from the consolidation seen in pneumonia. Additionally, pleural effusion is less likely to produce bronchial breath sounds or inspiratory crackles, as the fluid accumulation typically dampens lung sounds. C. Aspergilloma: Aspergillomas are fungal balls caused by Aspergillus species, typically forming in pre-existing lung cavities (e.g., from tuberculosis). They are usually asymptomatic but can present with hemoptysis. This patient's acute presentation, including rust-colored sputum and fever, does not fit the chronic course or imaging findings associated with an aspergilloma. D. Aspiration pneumonia: Aspiration pneumonia occurs due to inhalation of oropharyngeal or gastric contents, often in individuals with impaired swallowing or altered consciousness. It typically affects the dependent lung zones (e.g., posterior segments of the upper lobes or superior segments of the lower lobes) rather than the right middle lobe. The absence of a history suggesting aspiration, such as alcohol use, seizures, or dysphagia, makes this diagnosis less likely.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man develops a pustular lesion at the site of a cat scratch on his forearm. this is followed 1 week later by malaise, fever, and lymphadenopathy. on examination temperature is 100 f, pulse 100/min,bp-100/70 mmhg. he has tender axillary lymph nodes. chest and cvs examination is normal. which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Bartonella henselae. This patient’s clinical presentation is characteristic of cat-scratch disease (CSD), caused by Bartonella henselae. The key features include a pustular lesion at the site of a cat scratch, followed by systemic symptoms like fever and malaise, along with regional lymphadenopathy (in this case, tender axillary lymph nodes). Cat-scratch disease is commonly associated with contact with cats, particularly kittens, and usually resolves without treatment in immunocompetent individuals. Incorrect Options: B. Bartonella bacilliformis: This organism is the cause of Carrion’s disease, which is transmitted by sandflies in endemic areas (e.g., Peru, Colombia, and Ecuador). It presents with a biphasic illness, including an acute febrile stage (Oroya fever) and a chronic eruptive stage (verruga peruana). This patient’s lack of travel history to endemic areas and the absence of such symptoms make this diagnosis unlikely. C. Bartonella quintana: Bartonella quintana causes trench fever, which is transmitted by the human body louse and typically occurs in settings of poor hygiene or homelessness. It presents with recurrent fevers, headache, and shin pain, which are not features seen in this patient. The history of a cat scratch further excludes this organism as the causative agent. D. Coxiella burnetii: Coxiella burnetii causes Q fever, which is transmitted through inhalation of aerosols from infected animals (e.g., livestock). Q fever typically presents with flu-like symptoms, pneumonia, or hepatitis. There is no association with cat scratches or pustular skin lesions, making this an unlikely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child, unvaccinated, develops malaise, cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis with a high fever. examination of his mouth reveals blue white spots on a red base beside his second molars. the next day he develops an erythematous, nonpruritic, maculopapular rash at his hairline and behind his ears, which spreads over his body. which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Measles (rubeola). This child’s presentation is classic for measles, caused by the rubeola virus. The prodrome of malaise, cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, and high fever followed by the appearance of Koplik spots (blue-white spots on a red base near the second molars) is highly specific to measles. The subsequent erythematous, non-pruritic, maculopapular rash starting at the hairline and spreading downwards further confirms the diagnosis. Measles is more common in unvaccinated children due to the lack of protection from the measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine. Incorrect Options: A. Hand-foot-and-mouth disease (coxsackievirus): Hand-foot-and-mouth disease, caused by Coxsackievirus A16 or Enterovirus 71, typically presents with fever, malaise, and a vesicular rash on the hands, feet, and inside the mouth (e.g., on the buccal mucosa or tongue). The rash does not start at the hairline or spread in the same pattern as measles, and Koplik spots are not seen in this condition. C. Rubella (German measles): Rubella presents with a mild, pruritic maculopapular rash that begins on the face and spreads downward, but it is usually accompanied by mild fever, postauricular or occipital lymphadenopathy, and arthralgia in older children or adults. Koplik spots and the characteristic triad of cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis are absent in rubella. D. Mumps: Mumps typically causes fever, malaise, and parotid gland swelling, often associated with complications such as orchitis or meningitis. It does not cause a maculopapular rash or Koplik spots, making it an unlikely diagnosis for this patient.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with fever and malaise 6 weeks after mitral valve replacement. On examination, his temperature is 38°C, blood pressure 130/80 mm Hg, pulse 80/min, and a loud pansystolic murmur at the apex, which radiates to the axilla. He has no skin or neurologic findings. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Staphylococcus epidermidis. This patient presents with fever and malaise 6 weeks after mitral valve replacement, along with a new loud pansystolic murmur. These are concerning signs of infective endocarditis, which is a common complication following heart valve replacement. Staphylococcus epidermidis is the most likely causative organism, especially in the setting of prosthetic valve replacement. It is a coagulase-negative staphylococcus (CoNS) and is a common cause of infections in patients with prosthetic devices. It is often less virulent than Staphylococcus aureus, but it can form biofilms on prosthetic materials, making infections difficult to treat. Incorrect Options: A. Staphylococcus aureus: While Staphylococcus aureus is a common cause of infective endocarditis, it typically causes acute, severe infections with rapid progression, often associated with fever, chills, and septic emboli. This patient's more gradual onset of fever and malaise, with no neurological signs or skin findings (such as petechiae or splinter hemorrhages), and the timing (6 weeks post-operation) make Staphylococcus aureus less likely compared to Staphylococcus epidermidis. C. Staphylococcus saprophyticus: Staphylococcus saprophyticus is primarily associated with urinary tract infections, especially in young women, and is not a common cause of infective endocarditis, particularly in the context of a prosthetic valve replacement. Therefore, it is an unlikely causative organism in this case. D. Pneumococcus: Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumococcus) can cause endocarditis, but it is not typically associated with prosthetic valve infections. Pneumococcal endocarditis usually presents with acute symptoms and is more commonly seen in patients with pre-existing valvular heart disease, rather than in the context of prosthetic valve replacement.

questions.text: A 73-year-old man from a nursing home develops headache, fever, cough, sore throat, malaise, and severe myalgia during a community outbreak affecting numerous other residents at the home. The symptoms gradually resolve after 3 days, and he starts feeling better but then there is a reappearance of his fever, with cough and yellow sputum production. On examination, his temperature is 38.5°C, pulse 100/min, respiration 24/min, oxygen saturation 88% and crackles in the right lower lung base, bronchial breath sounds and dullness on percussion. CXR reveals a new infiltrate in the right lower lobe. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Streptococcus pneumoniae. This patient presents with an initial viral-like illness, followed by the reappearance of fever, cough, yellow sputum, and new signs of pneumonia, including crackles, bronchial breath sounds, and dullness to percussion. These findings suggest bacterial superinfection after an initial viral respiratory illness. Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common bacterial pathogen to cause secondary bacterial pneumonia after a viral infection, particularly in elderly patients. The chest X-ray showing a new infiltrate in the right lower lobe further supports this diagnosis. The yellow sputum suggests a bacterial cause, likely due to pus production, typical of a Streptococcus infection. Incorrect Options: A. Primary viral pneumonia: Primary viral pneumonia is typically characterized by a gradual onset of symptoms, often involving fever, cough, and fatigue, but it is less likely to cause a reappearance of symptoms after a period of improvement. While viral infections can cause pneumonia, this patient’s worsening symptoms with a new localized lung infiltrate and bacterial sputum production point towards a bacterial superinfection, not a primary viral infection. B. An autoimmune reaction: An autoimmune reaction could potentially cause symptoms such as fever, myalgia, and fatigue, but it is not a common cause of pneumonia. The signs of localized lung consolidation, including crackles, bronchial breath sounds, and dullness to percussion, are more indicative of a bacterial pneumonia rather than an autoimmune process. Autoimmune diseases like lupus or rheumatoid arthritis can cause pulmonary symptoms but do not typically present with this acute pattern of infection. C. Mycoplasma pneumoniae: Mycoplasma pneumoniae can cause pneumonia, but it is more often associated with a gradual onset of symptoms (dry cough, headache, and mild fever) that persist for weeks, rather than the acute worsening and localized findings seen in this patient. It also does not typically cause significant sputum production or consolidation as seen on the chest X-ray.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man is having intermittent fevers and malaise for the past 2 weeks. He has no other localizing symptoms. Two months ago, he had valve replacement surgery for a bicuspid aortic valve. A mechanical valve was inserted and his postoperative course was uncomplicated. On examination, his temperature is 38°C, blood pressure 124/80 mm Hg, pulse 72/min, and head and neck are normal. There is a 3/6 systolic ejection murmur, the second heart sound is mechanical, and a 2/6 early diastolic murmur is heard. The lungs are clear and the skin examination is normal. Three sets of blood cultures are drawn and an urgent echocardiogram is ordered. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Coagulase-negative staphylococcus (CoNS). This patient is presenting with intermittent fevers and malaise, along with a history of valve replacement surgery, which raises concern for infective endocarditis (IE), particularly involving a prosthetic valve. Coagulase-negative staphylococci (CoNS), such as Staphylococcus epidermidis, are the most common causative organisms in prosthetic valve endocarditis. CoNS are part of the normal skin flora and are opportunistic pathogens that often infect prosthetic devices, forming biofilms on the valve surface, which makes treatment challenging. The mechanical nature of the valve further predisposes the patient to these infections. The new murmurs, particularly the diastolic murmur, can also be indicative of endocarditis-related valvular changes. Incorrect Options: A. Staphylococcus aureus: While Staphylococcus aureus is a common cause of infective endocarditis, it typically causes more acute and severe infections. It is known for causing high fever, rapid progression of symptoms, and complications such as septic emboli. The patient’s more indolent presentation (2 weeks of intermittent fever and malaise) and the absence of signs like skin lesions or septic emboli make Staphylococcus aureus less likely as the causative organism in this case. CoNS are more typical in the setting of prosthetic valve endocarditis, as seen here. C. S. viridans: Streptococcus viridans is a common cause of infective endocarditis, particularly in patients with underlying native valve disease, dental procedures, or poor oral hygiene. However, it is less frequently seen in prosthetic valve endocarditis, where CoNS are more prevalent. The patient’s prosthetic valve and the absence of risk factors for S. viridans (e.g., dental procedures or poor oral hygiene) make this organism less likely. D. Enterococci: Enterococci are also a potential cause of infective endocarditis, particularly in patients with urinary tract infections, gastrointestinal procedures, or those with native valve disease. However, they are not the most common organisms responsible for prosthetic valve endocarditis, where CoNS are more prevalent. While Enterococci can cause infections in the setting of prosthetic valves, the patient’s history and presentation are more consistent with CoNS.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman visits her physician because of 3 weeks of a “flu-like” illness. She reports symptoms of malaise, fever, fatigue, and a sore throat. There is no weight loss or night sweats, and she has not traveled out of country. Her past medical history is not significant and she is not taking any medications. Physical examination is normal except for enlarged cervical lymph nodes. Laboratory data show hemoglobin 13.2 g/dL; hematocrit 42%; platelets 380,000/mL; WBC 8500/uL, with 35% segmented neutrophils, 1% eosinophils, and 64% lymphocytes, of which 36% were atypical. A heterophil antibody (sheep cell agglutination) test is negative. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) CMV (Cytomegalovirus). This patient presents with a flu-like illness including malaise, fever, fatigue, and sore throat, accompanied by enlarged cervical lymph nodes. Laboratory results show a mild lymphocytosis with a predominance of atypical lymphocytes, which is suggestive of a viral infection. A negative heterophil antibody test (which is commonly used to diagnose Epstein-Barr Virus [EBV]-related mononucleosis) rules out EBV. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is a leading cause of mononucleosis-like syndrome, particularly in young adults. CMV can present with similar symptoms to EBV infection but is often distinguished by a negative heterophil antibody test, as seen in this case. Therefore, CMV is the most likely causative organism. Incorrect Options: A. Herpes simplex: Herpes simplex virus typically causes localized lesions (oral or genital), and while it can cause a viral sore throat, it does not commonly present with generalized symptoms such as prolonged malaise, fever, and lymphadenopathy without oral or genital lesions. The patient’s presentation is more consistent with a systemic viral infection, making CMV a more likely cause than herpes simplex. B. Echovirus: Echovirus, a member of the enterovirus family, can cause febrile illnesses with symptoms like sore throat and lymphadenopathy, but it more commonly presents with gastrointestinal or respiratory symptoms rather than the typical mononucleosis-like syndrome seen with CMV. The negative heterophil antibody test also points away from Echovirus, as it is not a common cause of mononucleosis-like illness. D. Coxsackievirus: Coxsackievirus infections can cause a range of illnesses, including hand-foot-and-mouth disease and viral meningitis. It can also cause sore throat and fever, but it typically does not present with prolonged malaise and lymphadenopathy seen here. Additionally, Coxsackievirus does not typically cause the marked atypical lymphocytosis observed in this case, further supporting CMV as the most likely cause.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman visits your office because of headache, malaise, anorexia, pain in both sides of her jaw, and discomfort in both lower abdominal quadrants. Physical examination reveals enlarged parotid glands; bilateral lower quadrant abdominal tenderness; a temperature of 38.7°C; and a pulse rate of 92/min. Serologic testing (IgM) confirms the diagnosis of mumps. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Symptomatic. Mumps is a viral illness caused by the mumps virus, which typically presents with fever, headache, malaise, and swelling of the parotid glands. This patient’s symptoms, including bilateral parotid swelling and abdominal pain, are consistent with a diagnosis of mumps, confirmed by serologic testing. Mumps is self-limited, and the treatment is symptomatic, focusing on relieving pain and inflammation (e.g., with analgesics and fluids) while the body’s immune system fights off the virus. There is no specific antiviral therapy available for mumps, making symptomatic management the most appropriate treatment. Incorrect Options: B. Steroids: Steroids are not indicated for the treatment of mumps in the absence of specific complications (such as orchitis or severe inflammation). In fact, the routine use of steroids for viral infections like mumps is not recommended because they can suppress the immune response, potentially prolonging the infection or leading to further complications. Hence, steroids are not part of the standard treatment protocol for mumps. C. Broad-spectrum antibiotics: Antibiotics are used to treat bacterial infections, but mumps is caused by a virus, not bacteria. Since antibiotics do not affect viral infections, they are not appropriate for the treatment of mumps. In some cases, bacterial superinfections (e.g., pneumonia, otitis media) can occur, but antibiotics would only be required in such cases if a secondary bacterial infection was diagnosed. D. Sulfonamides: Sulfonamides are a type of antibiotic that would be inappropriate for the treatment of mumps, as it is a viral infection. Like broad-spectrum antibiotics, sulfonamides are used for bacterial infections and would not help in managing a viral illness like mumps. There is no role for sulfonamides in the treatment of mumps.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with fever, headache, photophobia, and neck discomfort in the middle of summer. He is alert and oriented, but has neck pain with flexion and extension of the head. His fundi are normal, and there are no focal neurologic findings or skin changes. A lumbar puncture reveals normal protein and glucose with a cell count of 240/mL (90% lymphocytes). Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Enterovirus (coxsackievirus or echovirus). This patient’s presentation of fever, headache, photophobia, neck discomfort, and a predominance of lymphocytes in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) strongly suggests viral (aseptic) meningitis. The CSF findings of normal protein and glucose levels with a moderately elevated white blood cell count (240/mL) and a lymphocytic predominance are typical for viral meningitis. Enteroviruses, such as coxsackievirus and echovirus, are the most common causative organisms of viral meningitis, especially in the summer months. These viruses cause a benign and self-limited condition, which is reflected by the patient’s stable neurological examination and absence of focal deficits. Incorrect Options: B. Streptococcus pneumoniae: Streptococcus pneumoniae is a common bacterial pathogen responsible for meningitis, but it typically causes a more severe, acute illness. Bacterial meningitis often presents with a rapid onset of high fever, significant headache, neck stiffness, altered mental status, and an elevated white blood cell count in the CSF (usually with a predominance of neutrophils). The normal protein and glucose levels in this patient’s CSF make bacterial meningitis, including Streptococcus pneumoniae, unlikely. C. Neisseria meningitides: Similar to Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitides is a bacterial pathogen that can cause meningitis. However, it also typically presents with a more severe, rapid onset of symptoms, including fever, headache, photophobia, neck stiffness, and altered mental status. The CSF findings in Neisseria meningitides meningitis usually show an elevated white blood cell count (predominantly neutrophils), low glucose, and elevated protein. The patient's CSF results do not support a bacterial etiology, making Neisseria meningitides less likely. D. Listeria monocytogenes: Listeria monocytogenes can cause bacterial meningitis, particularly in neonates, older adults, and immunocompromised individuals. It typically presents with fever, headache, and neck stiffness, but like other bacterial causes, it would show a significantly elevated white blood cell count in the CSF with a predominance of neutrophils, along with a decrease in glucose levels. The normal glucose and protein levels in this patient’s CSF rule out Listeria monocytogenes as the causative organism.

questions.text: An 18-year-old woman has eaten homemade preserves. Eighteen hours later, she develops diplopia, dysarthria, and dysphagia.She started complaining of weakness which progresses rapidly to involve neck,arms and legs.She then develops nausea,vomiting and abdominal pain.There is no fever and no sensory complaints, Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Clostridium botulinum toxin. This patient’s symptoms, which include diplopia, dysarthria, dysphagia, and rapidly progressive weakness affecting the neck, arms, and legs, are highly suggestive of botulism. Botulism is caused by a neurotoxin produced by Clostridium botulinum, often after ingestion of contaminated food, such as improperly prepared home-canned or preserved foods. The classic presentation includes cranial nerve involvement (e.g., diplopia, dysphagia) followed by descending flaccid paralysis, which starts in the upper limbs and progresses to the lower limbs. The absence of fever and sensory changes further supports this diagnosis, as botulism typically does not involve fever or sensory deficits. Incorrect Options: B. Staphylococcal toxin: Staphylococcal food poisoning, caused by ingestion of food contaminated with Staphylococcus aureus enterotoxins, typically presents with rapid onset of vomiting, nausea, and abdominal cramps, often within 1-6 hours of ingestion. However, it does not cause neurological symptoms such as diplopia, dysarthria, or descending paralysis, which are characteristic of botulism. Staphylococcal toxin is not associated with the progressive neurological deficits seen in this patient. C. Salmonellosis: Salmonella infection typically causes gastroenteritis, presenting with symptoms such as diarrhea, abdominal cramps, nausea, and vomiting, usually within 6-48 hours of ingestion. While Salmonella can cause fever and abdominal pain, it does not typically present with neurological symptoms such as diplopia, dysarthria, and ascending or descending paralysis. The absence of diarrhea and the rapid progression of weakness in this patient make Salmonella an unlikely cause. D. Brucellosis: Brucellosis, caused by Brucella species, is a zoonotic infection that typically presents with fever, fatigue, malaise, muscle and joint pain, and sometimes hepatosplenomegaly. It may also cause abdominal pain, but it is not associated with acute neurological symptoms like diplopia, dysphagia, or descending paralysis. The presentation here, especially with the rapid progression of weakness and cranial nerve involvement, is more indicative of botulism than brucellosis.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy has a severe sore throat with fever and dysphagia. On examination, there are grayish-white papulovesicular lesions on an erythematous base that ulcerate. They are located on the soft palate, anterior pillars of the tonsils and uvula. There are no lesions on the gingiva, tongue, or lips. A clinical diagnosis of herpangina is made. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Coxsackievirus A. This child’s presentation of a severe sore throat, fever, dysphagia, and grayish-white papulovesicular lesions located on the soft palate, anterior pillars of the tonsils, and uvula is consistent with herpangina, a viral infection caused by Coxsackievirus A. Herpangina is characterized by vesicular lesions in the oropharynx, particularly on the soft palate and tonsils, with a characteristic pattern of ulceration. It typically affects children, especially during the summer and fall months, and is associated with fever, sore throat, and difficulty swallowing. The absence of lesions on the lips, tongue, and gingiva further supports the diagnosis of herpangina, which is specifically caused by Coxsackievirus A. Incorrect Options: A. Measles: Measles (rubeola) presents with a prodrome of cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, and a characteristic Koplik's spots (small white spots with a red base) inside the mouth, usually on the buccal mucosa. These spots occur before the characteristic maculopapular rash appears. Measles does not cause papulovesicular lesions on the soft palate, anterior pillars of the tonsils, or uvula, as seen in this case. Therefore, measles is an unlikely cause of this child’s symptoms. B. Rubella: Rubella (German measles) typically presents with a mild fever, rash that begins on the face and spreads to the rest of the body, and posterior auricular lymphadenopathy. It does not cause vesicular lesions on the soft palate or tonsils as seen in this child. Rubella’s oral findings are generally mild, and it is not associated with the ulcerative lesions characteristic of herpangina. D. HSV-1: Herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) is a common cause of oral lesions, such as cold sores, but it typically affects the lips, gums, and tongue. While HSV-1 can cause lesions in the oral cavity, these lesions are usually painful, grouped vesicles that ulcerate and are often located on the lips and surrounding areas, not the soft palate or tonsils. Additionally, HSV-1 infections often cause more localized lesions, whereas herpangina caused by Coxsackievirus A typically affects the posterior oropharynx without involvement of the lips or gingiva.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man developed a cough shortly after returning from a 1-month hiking trip. During his trip, he had developed a flu-like illness consisting of fever, cough, and muscle pains, which resolved spontaneously. A CXR shows a thin-walled cavity in the right upper lobe, and the sputum reveals fungal elements. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Coccidioidomycosis. The patient’s history of flu-like symptoms followed by the development of a cough after a hiking trip, along with the finding of a thin-walled cavity in the right upper lobe on the chest X-ray, is highly suggestive of coccidioidomycosis. This fungal infection is caused by Coccidioides species, commonly found in arid regions such as the southwestern United States, parts of Mexico, and Central and South America. The infection typically presents with flu-like symptoms, including fever, cough, and muscle aches, and can progress to more severe forms, such as pulmonary cavitary lesions. The identification of fungal elements in the sputum further supports this diagnosis. Coccidioides can cause chronic pulmonary disease, which may lead to the formation of cavities in the lungs, especially in immunocompetent individuals who have had prior exposure. Incorrect Options: B. Cryptococcus neoformans: Cryptococcus neoformans is a fungal pathogen that typically causes pneumonia or meningitis, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. It is not associated with the formation of lung cavities as commonly as Coccidioides species. Cryptococcus is typically found in pigeon droppings and can cause chronic lung infection, but it is not as likely to present with a thin-walled cavity in the upper lobe of the lung, as seen in this case. C. Candida albicans: Candida albicans is an opportunistic fungal pathogen that can cause mucosal infections, skin infections, or systemic infections, particularly in immunocompromised hosts. It is less likely to cause pulmonary cavities, especially in immunocompetent individuals. It is more commonly associated with candidemia, oral thrush, and superficial infections, rather than the pulmonary findings seen here. D. Mycobacteria: Although Mycobacterium tuberculosis (TB) and other mycobacteria can cause lung cavities, the patient’s history of hiking and the absence of other classic TB symptoms (e.g., weight loss, night sweats) makes tuberculosis less likely in this case. Furthermore, TB typically presents with more gradual onset symptoms, and the thin-walled cavity in the right upper lobe is more consistent with a fungal infection, such as coccidioidomycosis, than with mycobacterial infection.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy from a rural area has never been vaccinated appropriately. He develops fever, cough, and coryza. The next day, blue white spots develop on the buccal mucosa. On the third day, an erythematous, nonpruritic maculopapular rash develops on the face and spreads over the entire body. Which of the following is the most likely complication?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Otitis media. The clinical presentation of the 8-year-old boy—fever, cough, coryza, and the characteristic appearance of blue-white spots (Koplik spots) on the buccal mucosa, followed by the development of a maculopapular rash starting on the face and spreading over the body—suggests a diagnosis of measles (rubeola). Measles is a highly contagious viral infection, and one of the most common complications in children with measles is otitis media (middle ear infection). This occurs due to the viral infection disrupting the normal function of the Eustachian tube, which can lead to bacterial superinfection and fluid accumulation in the middle ear. Otitis media is a common complication, especially in unvaccinated children, and can result in pain, fever, and hearing loss. Incorrect Options: A. Pneumonia: While pneumonia is a well-known complication of measles and can be serious, otitis media is generally more common. Measles-related pneumonia occurs due to secondary bacterial infections or as a direct result of the viral infection. However, in an unvaccinated child presenting with measles, otitis media is typically more frequent and would be considered the most likely complication in this scenario. B. Encephalitis: Encephalitis is a rare but severe complication of measles that can lead to permanent brain damage or death. However, it occurs in a small percentage of cases (about 1 in 1,000) and is more likely in those with weakened immune systems. Given that the boy's main symptoms are typical for measles, otitis media is more likely than encephalitis in this case, especially in a previously healthy child. D. Bronchitis: While bronchitis, characterized by inflammation of the bronchial tubes, can occur during a respiratory viral infection like measles, it is less commonly a direct complication compared to otitis media. Bronchitis could be associated with the viral illness but is not typically considered one of the primary complications of measles, especially when compared to ear infections.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy develops symptoms of cough, fever, and malaise followed by a generalized maculopapular rash that has spread from the head downwards. A clinical diagnosis of measles is made. A few days after the onset of the rash he is drowsy, lethargic, and complaining of headache. A lumbar puncture, electroencephalogram (EEG), and computerized tomography (CT) of the brain exclude other etiologies and confirm the diagnosis of encephalitis. Which of the following is the most likely delayed neurologic complication of measles virus encephalitis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Mental retardation or epilepsy. The scenario described is consistent with measles virus encephalitis, which is a rare but serious complication of measles. The most concerning delayed neurologic complication of measles encephalitis is subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE), a progressive, debilitating, and often fatal disease. SSPE typically develops several years after a measles infection and can lead to mental retardation, epilepsy, personality changes, and motor dysfunction. It is a result of persistent viral infection of the brain due to defective measles virus, and it causes progressive neurological deterioration. This complication is more common in children who had measles at a young age, particularly those who were not vaccinated. Incorrect Options: A. Meningitis: Meningitis is an inflammation of the membranes surrounding the brain and spinal cord and can occur as a complication of many viral infections, including measles. However, meningitis is not the typical delayed complication after measles encephalitis. Measles encephalitis itself can cause initial neurologic symptoms like fever, headache, and altered mental status, but meningitis is not a characteristic delayed outcome. The delayed complications are more likely to involve cognitive and neurological decline such as epilepsy or developmental delays, which are seen in SSPE. B. Pure motor paralysis: Pure motor paralysis, such as seen in conditions like poliomyelitis, is not a common delayed complication of measles. While measles virus can cause encephalitis and other neurological issues, motor paralysis is not a hallmark feature of the delayed effects of measles. In cases of measles encephalitis or SSPE, neurological symptoms such as seizures, mental retardation, and epilepsy are more commonly seen rather than isolated motor paralysis. C. Autonomic neuropathy: Autonomic neuropathy involves dysfunction of the autonomic nervous system, which controls involuntary functions such as heart rate, digestion, and respiratory rate. While measles and its complications can involve the central nervous system, autonomic neuropathy is not a known or common delayed complication of measles infection. The most significant delayed complications are more likely related to cognitive decline and epilepsy rather than autonomic dysfunction.

choices.text: Examination of a dried stool specimen
Examination of a wet stool specimen

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents with diarrhea. Over the past few days, he has gradually developed lower abdominal pain and diarrhea. Now the symptoms are much worse with eight stools a day consisting mostly of mucus and blood. He is afebrile, the abdomen is tender in left lower quadrant, and the remaining examination is normal. His stool is mostly comprised of blood and mucus. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial diagnostic test?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Examination of a wet stool specimen. In this case, the patient is presenting with diarrhea, lower abdominal pain, and bloody stools, which are suggestive of a gastrointestinal infection. The presence of blood and mucus in the stool, along with localized tenderness in the left lower quadrant, indicates the possibility of inflammatory diarrhea or dysentery, which could be caused by organisms such as Shigella, Entamoeba histolytica, or other enteric pathogens. The most appropriate initial diagnostic test is to perform an examination of a wet stool specimen. This test allows for the direct observation of motile organisms such as protozoa (like Entamoeba histolytica) or bacteria (like Shigella) that might be causing the diarrhea. A wet mount helps visualize trophozoites or motile bacteria in the stool, which is important in identifying the etiology of the infection quickly. It can also help detect white blood cells or red blood cells that are common in cases of inflammatory diarrhea. Incorrect Options: A. Stool culture: A stool culture is indeed helpful in identifying bacterial pathogens like Salmonella, Shigella, and Campylobacter that cause bloody diarrhea. However, stool culture is typically a more prolonged process, taking 24-48 hours to obtain results. While important for confirming the exact bacterial pathogen, it is not the most appropriate initial diagnostic test for immediate findings in cases with clear evidence of inflammatory diarrhea, where a wet mount can provide quicker information. In this case, starting with a wet mount is more practical for rapid assessment. B. Stool toxin assay: Stool toxin assays, such as those for Clostridium difficile toxin or other enteric pathogens, are useful when there is suspicion of specific toxin-producing organisms causing diarrhea, such as C. difficile or enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC). However, in this patient, the clinical signs (bloody stools, lower quadrant tenderness) are more consistent with inflammatory diarrhea, which is often caused by bacterial infections (like Shigella or Salmonella) or parasitic infections (like Entamoeba histolytica). Toxin assays are more specific for particular pathogens, but a wet mount is better suited for this scenario, as it can help identify the most likely cause of dysentery or inflammatory diarrhea early on. C. Examination of a dried stool specimen: A dried stool specimen is not typically used for diagnosing infectious causes of diarrhea. It is not effective in detecting pathogens like bacteria, parasites, or viruses in a stool sample. The preferred method for examining stool for infectious causes is a wet mount because it preserves the motility of organisms and allows for the identification of parasites or bacteria that might be contributing to the symptoms.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is sent to the emergency room because of clinical suspicion of meningitis. He has been ill for 2 days with fever and lethargy. On examination, he is febrile, the neck is stiff, and papilledema is present. There is no rash, the lungs are clear, and heart sounds normal. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Streptococcus pneumoniae. In a child with fever, lethargy, stiff neck, and papilledema (suggestive of increased intracranial pressure), the clinical presentation strongly points to bacterial meningitis. The most likely causative organism for bacterial meningitis in children, especially those aged 4 years, is Streptococcus pneumoniae, a common cause of community-acquired bacterial meningitis in this age group. It is particularly prevalent in children who have not received the full series of pneumococcal vaccines, which is important to consider in this patient. S. pneumoniae is responsible for a significant portion of bacterial meningitis cases and typically presents with symptoms such as fever, nausea, vomiting, and neck stiffness. Papilledema, a sign of increased intracranial pressure, further supports the diagnosis of meningitis. Streptococcus pneumoniae is often seen in children who are unvaccinated or inadequately vaccinated. Incorrect Options: A. Neisseria meningitidis: While Neisseria meningitidis is a common cause of bacterial meningitis, especially in adolescents and young adults, it is less common in children aged 4 years compared to S. pneumoniae. N. meningitidis is associated with petechial or purpuric rash (which is not present in this case), and it tends to cause epidemic outbreaks in settings such as schools or military barracks, or it can affect people in close living conditions. Therefore, S. pneumoniae remains the more likely cause in a 4-year-old child with no rash. C. Haemophilus influenzae: Haemophilus influenzae was historically a common cause of bacterial meningitis in children. However, the incidence of H. influenzae type b (Hib) has dramatically decreased due to the widespread use of the Hib vaccine. Therefore, while H. influenzae can still cause meningitis, it is much less common in a vaccinated child. In this case, unless the child has not been vaccinated, S. pneumoniae is a more likely cause than H. influenzae. D. Staphylococcus: Staphylococcus species, including Staphylococcus aureus and coagulase-negative staphylococci, are more commonly associated with healthcare-associated infections (such as post-surgical meningitis or meningitis in immunocompromised individuals). It is less likely to be the causative organism in a 4-year-old child presenting with typical signs of acute bacterial meningitis and without a history of recent surgery or immunocompromised status. Staphylococcus infections are also less likely to present with papilledema as an initial sign.

choices.text: A high level of circulating immune complexes

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with chills and rigors. She looks unwell, and her temperature is 39.4°C, blood pressure 100/60 mm Hg, pulse 110/min, and oxygen saturation 95%. There is a 3/6 pansystolic murmur at the right sternal border, which increases with inspiration. Her arms have multiple tattoos and needle marks from injection drug use. Blood cultures (2/2 sets) are positive for S. aureus, and she is started on appropriate antibiotics. Her renal function is mildly impaired and her urinalysis is positive for protein, and microscopy reveals red cell casts. Which of the following mechanisms is the most likely explanation for her renal abnormalities?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) A high level of circulating immune complexes. The patient presents with signs of infective endocarditis, including chills, fever, a pansystolic murmur, and a history of intravenous drug use. The positive blood cultures for Staphylococcus aureus confirm the diagnosis. The renal abnormalities in this case, characterized by proteinuria, red cell casts, and mildly impaired renal function, are most likely due to the formation of immune complexes in response to the ongoing infection. Immune complexes can deposit in the kidneys (specifically in the glomeruli), leading to glomerulonephritis, which can manifest with proteinuria, hematuria, and red cell casts in the urine. This type of renal involvement is common in infective endocarditis, especially with Staphylococcus aureus infections. Incorrect Options: A. Septic emboli: While septic emboli can occur in infective endocarditis and can potentially affect the kidneys, they typically present with acute kidney injury due to embolization to the renal vasculature, often leading to acute infarction or abscess formation. This would likely result in flank pain, hematuria, and signs of acute kidney injury, rather than the proteinuria and red cell casts seen in this patient. The absence of typical signs of septic emboli (like acute renal pain or visible infarcts) makes this less likely. B. Cardiac failure with prerenal azotemia: Although the patient has hypotension and tachycardia, which could suggest cardiovascular compromise, there is no clear evidence of congestive heart failure or decreased renal perfusion in this case. Prerenal azotemia is typically associated with elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine due to decreased renal perfusion, but the renal findings here (specifically proteinuria and red cell casts) suggest a more glomerular issue, likely due to immune complex-mediated glomerulonephritis, rather than prerenal azotemia. D. Fungal disease: Although fungal infections can cause infective endocarditis, especially in immunocompromised individuals, there is no indication in this case that the patient has risk factors for fungal infections (such as immunosuppression or prolonged intravenous catheter use). The patient has a known risk factor for bacterial infective endocarditis (intravenous drug use), and the blood cultures grew Staphylococcus aureus, which is a bacterial pathogen. Thus, fungal disease is unlikely to be the cause of her renal abnormalities.

questions.text: A 22-year-old university student complains of fatigue and malaise for the past 2 weeks. She also reports feeling feverish, and recently had a sore throat. Physical examination reveals enlarged tonsils and palpable cervical lymph nodes. There is also tenderness in the right upper quadrant on deep palpation, and minimal splenomegaly. Laboratory data show hemoglobin 13 g/dL; hematocrit 40%; platelets 340,000/mL; WBC 9400/mL, with 35% segmented neutrophils, 1% eosinophils, and 64% lymphocytes, of which 36% were atypical. A heterophil antibody (sheep cell agglutination) test is positive. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Adequate rest. The patient presents with classic signs of infectious mononucleosis, which is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV). Her symptoms of fatigue, malaise, fever, sore throat, enlarged tonsils, cervical lymphadenopathy, and splenomegaly, along with atypical lymphocytes on the laboratory findings, are all consistent with this diagnosis. The positive heterophil antibody test confirms the diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis. In general, infectious mononucleosis is a self-limited viral infection and the most important treatment is supportive care. The recommended management includes adequate rest, maintaining hydration, and fever control with antipyretics (like acetaminophen or ibuprofen). Antibiotics and steroids are typically not required unless there are specific complications. Incorrect Options: A. Gamma-globulin: Gamma-globulin (IVIg) is used in certain viral infections or immunodeficiency states, but it is not a treatment for infectious mononucleosis caused by Epstein-Barr virus (EBV). The condition is usually self-limited, and gamma-globulin is not indicated unless the patient has a complicated course or immunocompromised state. In this case, there are no signs of severe illness that would warrant this intervention. C. Steroids: Steroids may be considered in certain cases of infectious mononucleosis if there are severe complications such as airway obstruction due to tonsillar enlargement, or hemolytic anemia, but they are not routinely used in most cases. This patient does not show signs of such complications, so steroids are not necessary. In general, steroids should be avoided in mononucleosis unless there is a clear indication due to the risk of complications like splenic rupture. D. Ceftriaxone: Ceftriaxone is a broad-spectrum antibiotic used to treat bacterial infections. Since the patient's symptoms are due to a viral infection (EBV), antibiotics like ceftriaxone are not indicated. Furthermore, infectious mononucleosis is not caused by a bacterial pathogen and will not respond to antibiotics. The use of antibiotics in viral infections can lead to unnecessary side effects and the development of antibiotic resistance.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents with a painless chronic vulvar ulcer. The lesion began as a papule and then ulcerated. It has persisted for several months. Currently, physical examination reveals a painless elevated area of beefy red, friable granulation tissue. She has been sexually active for several years. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Intracellular Gram-negative bacteria. This patient's presentation of a painless chronic vulvar ulcer with a beefy red, friable granulation tissue is highly suggestive of chancroid, which is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, an intracellular Gram-negative bacterium. Chancroid typically presents with painful genital ulcers that may be soft and have a friable base. The chronic, non-healing ulcer in this case may be due to a delayed diagnosis or inadequate treatment, leading to prolonged infection. The beefy red appearance of the ulcer is characteristic of granulation tissue, which is formed as part of the chronic inflammatory response to the infection. This condition is primarily transmitted through sexual contact, which aligns with the patient's sexual history. Incorrect Options: A. Spirochete: A spirochete is the causative organism for syphilis, which presents with a painless ulcer (chancre), typically with a hard, indurated border and a smooth base. The lesion described in this patient is painless, but the friable, beefy red granulation tissue is not characteristic of syphilitic ulcers, which tend to have a cleaner, less inflamed appearance. Additionally, syphilis progresses differently with systemic symptoms and later-stage complications, which this patient does not have. B. Gram-positive coccus: A Gram-positive coccus, such as Streptococcus or Staphylococcus, is responsible for causing cellulitis, abscesses, or impetigo, but these infections typically present with painful, erythematous lesions and pus or abscess formation. The description of a painless ulcer with granulation tissue is more consistent with a chronic ulcerative process, which is less likely caused by a Gram-positive coccus. Additionally, these organisms are not typically associated with chronic genital ulcers like the one in this case. D. Chronic viral infection: A chronic viral infection could refer to conditions like herpes simplex virus (HSV) or human papillomavirus (HPV). Herpes simplex typically presents with painful vesicles or ulcers that are often recurrent, not a single chronic ulcer. HPV can cause genital warts, but these lesions are papular or verrucous, not ulcerative. A chronic ulcer with granulation tissue as described in this patient is more consistent with a bacterial infection like chancroid, not a viral one.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents with headache, fever, and neck stiffness. On examination, her blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg, pulse 100/min, temperature 38.6°C, and the neck is stiff and painful to flex and extend. The ears, throat, and sinuses are normal, there are no focal neurologic signs, and the remaining examination is normal. There are no reported similar cases in the community. Which of the following is the most likely source of her infection?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Nasopharynx. This patient presents with symptoms suggestive of meningitis, including headache, fever, neck stiffness, and painful flexion/extension of the neck. The absence of focal neurologic signs and normal examination findings in other systems make the diagnosis of meningitis more likely. The most common cause of bacterial meningitis in young adults is Neisseria meningitidis, which typically originates from the nasopharynx. The bacteria can colonize the upper respiratory tract and, under certain conditions (e.g., stress, immunosuppression), can invade the bloodstream and cross the blood-brain barrier, causing meningitis. The lack of other reported cases in the community suggests a less likely outbreak, further supporting that the source is individual colonization from the nasopharynx. Incorrect Options: A. An infected heart valve: An infected heart valve (endocarditis) typically presents with fever, malaise, and murmurs, but it is not usually associated with the acute meningeal symptoms such as neck stiffness and pain on flexion/extension of the neck. While bacterial endocarditis can lead to septic emboli that may affect the brain, it is unlikely to present as isolated meningitis without other systemic signs. In addition, there is no history of heart disease or intravenous drug use in this patient to suggest endocarditis as the source of infection. C. Skin: Skin infections typically cause localized abscesses or cellulitis, rather than systemic infections such as meningitis. While bacteria like Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes can cause skin infections and subsequently lead to bacteremia, it is uncommon for these infections to cause meningitis without other obvious symptoms, such as pus or cellulitis at the site of infection. This patient's presentation, with prominent neurological signs and absence of localized skin findings, does not point to the skin as the source. D. Oral ingestion: Infections caused by oral ingestion typically lead to conditions such as gastroenteritis, food poisoning, or sometimes bacterial infections like typhoid fever or listeriosis, but these do not present with meningeal signs such as neck stiffness and headache. Although Listeria monocytogenes can cause meningitis after oral ingestion, it is usually associated with risk factors such as immunocompromised states, pregnancy, or age extremes (very young or elderly), none of which are described in this patient.

questions.text: A 44-year-old renal transplant patient develops severe cough and shortness of breath on exertion. On examination, he appears dyspneic, respirations 24/min, pulse 110/min, and oxygen saturation 88%. His lungs are clear on auscultation and heart sounds are normal. CXR shows bilateral diffuse perihilar infiltrates. Bronchoscopy and bronchial brushings show clusters of cysts that stain with methenamine silver. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. This patient is a renal transplant recipient presenting with cough, shortness of breath, and hypoxia. The bilateral perihilar infiltrates on chest X-ray, coupled with bronchoscopy showing cysts that stain with methenamine silver, are suggestive of Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP). This fungal infection is common in immunocompromised patients, such as those with renal transplants, and Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) is the first-line treatment for PCP. TMP-SMX both treats and prevents PCP, making it the most appropriate next step in management. It is also the preferred prophylactic agent for patients at high risk for PCP. Incorrect Options: A. Amphotericin B: Amphotericin B is typically used for serious fungal infections like Aspergillus, Cryptococcus, or histoplasmosis, but it is not effective against Pneumocystis jirovecii. Amphotericin B is more suitable for infections caused by systemic fungal organisms, whereas P. jirovecii is treated with agents like TMP-SMX, which is specific for this pathogen. B. Cephalosporins: Cephalosporins are broad-spectrum antibiotics that target bacterial infections. However, Pneumocystis jirovecii is a fungus, not a bacterium, and cephalosporins are ineffective against fungal infections. Therefore, this treatment option is not appropriate for this patient’s suspected PCP. D. Aminoglycosides: Aminoglycosides (e.g., gentamicin, tobramycin) are broad-spectrum antibiotics primarily used for treating gram-negative bacterial infections. They are not effective against fungal infections like Pneumocystis jirovecii. Given the patient's clinical presentation and the results of bronchial brushings, aminoglycosides would not address the underlying cause of the symptoms.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents with diarrhea 3 weeks after returning from a trip to rural area. Over the past few days, he has gradually developed lower abdominal pain and diarrhea. Now the symptoms are much worse with eight stools a day consisting mostly of mucus and blood. He is afebrile, the abdomen is tender in left lower quadrant, and the remaining examination is normal. His stool is mostly comprised of blood and mucus, and stools tests show trophozoites of Entamoeba histolytica. Which of the following is the most likely site of extraintestinal involvement?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Liver. This patient is presenting with bloody diarrhea, lower abdominal pain, and trophozoites of Entamoeba histolytica found in stool tests, which is characteristic of amoebic dysentery. Entamoeba histolytica is a protozoan parasite that primarily affects the colon but can also cause extraintestinal complications, particularly liver abscesses. The liver is the most common site of extraintestinal involvement in Entamoeba histolytica infection. The amoeba can invade the bloodstream, leading to the formation of amoebic liver abscesses, typically presenting with fever, right upper quadrant pain, and sometimes jaundice. Therefore, the liver is the most likely site of extraintestinal involvement in this patient. Incorrect Options: A. Genitals: Entamoeba histolytica does not typically cause infections of the genitals. While genital involvement may occur with other infections, such as Trichomonas vaginalis, it is not a known complication of amoebic dysentery. Therefore, this is not the most likely site of extraintestinal involvement in this case. B. Pleura: Pleural involvement with Entamoeba histolytica is rare and not a typical site for extraintestinal involvement. While certain infections like tuberculosis or fungal infections may cause pleural effusions or other pleural complications, amoebiasis usually affects the liver, lungs, or brain if it involves extraintestinal spread. Hence, pleura is an unlikely site of involvement in this case. C. Pericardium: Involvement of the pericardium is also not a common complication of Entamoeba histolytica. The pericardium can be affected in other infections, such as viral infections (e.g., coxsackievirus), but it is not typically associated with amoebiasis. Therefore, the pericardium is not a likely site of extraintestinal involvement in this patient.

choices.text: Single blood sample for a specific immunoglobulin G (IgG)
Single blood test for a specific immunoglobulin M (IgM)

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman complains of headache and discomfort in both sides of her jaw. Physical examination reveals enlarged parotid glands that are slightly tender on palpation. There is reddening of the orifice of Stensen’s duct on intra oral examination; her temperature is 38.3°C, and the pulse rate is 80/min. Laboratory data show hemoglobin 14 g/dL; hematocrit 40%; WBC 11000/mL, with 33% segmented neutrophils, 7% monocytes, and 60% lymphocytes. Which of the following diagnostic tests will help to confirm the diagnosis of epidemic parotitis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Single blood test for a specific immunoglobulin M (IgM). The patient is presenting with symptoms of epidemic parotitis (mumps), including headache, fever, tender parotid glands, and the reddening of Stensen’s duct, which are characteristic signs of the infection. To confirm the diagnosis of epidemic parotitis (mumps), the most appropriate diagnostic test is a single blood test for a specific immunoglobulin M (IgM) against the mumps virus. IgM is the acute-phase antibody produced early in the course of infection and can be detected in the blood during the first few days of illness. IgM testing is a reliable and specific method to diagnose mumps and can confirm the infection during its acute phase. Incorrect Options: A. Single blood sample for a specific immunoglobulin G (IgG): An IgG test would be used to assess past exposure to the mumps virus and immune status. While IgG antibodies can confirm previous infection or vaccination, they are not helpful for diagnosing an acute infection like mumps. The patient is presenting with acute symptoms, and IgM would be more useful for confirming recent infection. B. Blood cell count: The blood cell count may show mild leukocytosis (as seen in this patient with an elevated WBC count), but it is not specific for mumps. While an elevated white blood cell count can indicate an infection, it does not help in diagnosing the specific cause of the symptoms. Therefore, a blood cell count alone would not be diagnostic for mumps. C. Blood culture: A blood culture would be appropriate if a bacterial infection was suspected, such as sepsis or bacterial parotitis, but mumps is caused by a virus (the mumps virus), and blood cultures would not be helpful in diagnosing viral infections. Thus, blood culture is not an appropriate test for epidemic parotitis.

questions.text: Three hours after a birthday party eight people develop severe diarrhea which was watery without any blood or mucus. Other symptoms included nausea, vomiting, and abdominal cramps. There was no history of fever. Food served included chicken salad and cream-filled pastries. All affected individuals had the pastries. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Staphylococcal enterotoxin. The most likely causative organism for this foodborne illness is Staphylococcus aureus, which produces staphylococcal enterotoxin. This enterotoxin is a pre-formed toxin that can be ingested when food contaminated with Staphylococcus aureus is consumed. The symptoms of severe diarrhea, watery stools, nausea, vomiting, and abdominal cramps typically appear within 1-6 hours of consumption, which is consistent with this scenario. The absence of fever and the fact that all affected individuals ate cream-filled pastries (which can be a potential source of contamination) further point to staphylococcal enterotoxin as the most likely cause of the illness. Incorrect Options: B. C. botulinum: Clostridium botulinum causes botulism, which is a neuroparalytic disease often linked to improperly canned or preserved foods. While it can cause nausea, vomiting, and abdominal cramps, the symptoms of botulism are neurological in nature, such as diplopia, difficulty swallowing, and muscle weakness. The rapid onset of symptoms within hours of ingestion and the lack of neurological symptoms rule out botulism. C. Clostridium perfringens: Clostridium perfringens causes gastroenteritis with symptoms of diarrhea and abdominal cramps, typically occurring 6-24 hours after ingestion of contaminated food, such as undercooked meat or poultry. While this is a possible cause of food poisoning, it does not explain the rapid onset of symptoms (within 3 hours). Additionally, C. perfringens does not cause vomiting, which is a prominent symptom in this case. Thus, Staphylococcal enterotoxin is a more likely cause due to the fast onset and symptoms of vomiting and diarrhea. D. Salmonella species: Salmonella infections typically present with symptoms of fever, diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and nausea, but these symptoms usually begin 6-72 hours after ingestion of contaminated food, especially poultry, eggs, or dairy products. The lack of fever and the rapid onset of symptoms within 3 hours make Salmonella less likely in this case.
